abstract.text: In this paper, we present a new experimental progress in brief on the recent observation of the charged charmonium-like state Zc(4020) ± states and its iso-spin partner Zc(4020) 0 in the e + eC → π +,0 π −,0 hc process of at the BESIII experiment.
The charged Zc(4020) is its decay into π ± hc final state, and carries electric charge, thus it contains at least four quarks.
The observation of both charge and neutral state makes Zc(4020) the first iso-spin triplet Zc state observed in experiment.

body_text.text: I. INTRODUCTION
In quark model, hadrons are made up of quarks.
At the lowest configuration, one quark and one anti-quark form meson while three quarks do baryon [1].
But hadrons with other configurations, called exotic states, are not excluded, such as deuteron, which is formed with a proton and a neutron [2,3].
The search for these exotic states has stimulated great interest.

Although no convincible evidence has been found in experimental, strong evidence for mesons that do not fit into the simple qq-bar scheme of the quark model has been accumulating during the past decade, such as X(3872) [4][5][6][7], Y(4260) [8], Z(4430) + [9][10][11][12] in charmonium region.
Experimentally, what important to establish exotic states is finding clear different signatures compared with the conventional hadrons.

One promising method is to search for electrically charged states that can decay into hidden charm final states, since such states contain at least four quarks, and therefore can not be conventional mesons, if they are mesons.
In charmonium region, the first such state reported in experiment is Z(4430) + from Belle in 2008 in a study of B → Kπ + ψ(2S) decays [9].
This state has not been confirmed from BaBar [11] using the same analysis method.
Until the result reported by LHCb in 2014 [12], the Z(4430) + has been confirmed with ambitious significance, and the quantum number is determined to be 1 + .
The first confirmed charged charmoniumlike state is Z c (3900) observed in π ± J/ψ mass spectrum in the e + e − → π + π − J/ψ process at BESIII using data sample taken at √ s = 4.26 GeV [13].
This state has been confirmed shortly by Belle experiment [14] and CLEO-c [15] using same decay mode.
Besides, in CLEO-c data, an evidence of neutral Z c (3900) has also been reported in the neutral process.
The observation of Z c (3900) has attracted great interest from both theoretical and experimental side.

Different models have been proposed, such as tetraquark consisting of cu andcd diquarks [16], molecule consisting of D * and D [17], hadroquarkonium consisting of ud bound to a color-singlet cc core [18], or other configurations [19].

Almost in the same, the study of the (DD * ) ± and (D * D * ) ± system in (DD * ) ± π and (D * D * ) ± π states in the same data sample have been performed, and strong near-threshold peaks has been observed, which is named as Z c (3885) [20] and Z c (4025) [23], respectively.
Apparently, searching for similar states in the invariant mass spectrum made up of one pion and other charmonium states such as h c , χ cJ , and so on is interesting.
Any observation may provide more information on understanding these states, and helpful in building relationship between those states.
Such studies have been performed at BESIII in both e + e − → π + π − h c and π 0 π 0 h c processes [21,22].
A distinctive structure, named as Z c (4020) has been observed in the invariant mass spectrum of πh c .
The mass of Z c (4020) is close to that of the mentioned Z c (4025) ± observed in (D * D * ) ± π states.
Here we just introduce the observation of both electrically charged and neutral Z c (4020) at BESIII.

The process of e + e − → π + π − h c was first observed by CLEO-c experiment using 586 pb The BESIII experiment, works at the Beijing Electron Positron Collider (BEPC) II, is a tau-charm factory which can collect data from √ s = 2 GeV to 4.6 GeV [24].

Starting from the end of 2012 to 2013, BESIII detector collected about 3.3 fb −1 data samples at 13 CM energies from 3.900 to 4.420 GeV, which are listed in Table I. Based on these data samples, the process of e + e − → ππh c has been studied using full reconstruction of the final state particles.
Here the h c is reconstructed via its electric-dipole (E1) transition h c → γη c with η c reconstructed with its 16 hadronic decay modes: pp, π

The γη c mass spectrum is used to extract the number of π + π − h c signal events by performing a fit.

At the energy points with large statistics (4.230, 4.260, and 4.360 GeV), the fit is applied to the 16 η c decay modes simultaneously, while at other energy points, the fit is performed to the mass spectrum summed over all the η c decay modes.

With the fitted number of hc events and the corresponding detect efficiency as well as the integrated luminosity at each energy point, the cross section of e + e − → π + π − h c at different energy points are listed in Table I.

The comparison of the cross section of e + e − → π + π − h c measured at BESIII with the cross section of e + e − → π + π − J/ψ measured at Belle experiment using initial state radiative (ISR) method [14] is shown in Figure1.
The cross section of e + e − → π 0 π 0 h c is at the same order of magnitude of π + π − J/ψ but with a different line shape.
There is a possible broad structure at high energy with a local maximum around 4.23 GeV.
Since the Y(4260) was established from the cross section of e + e − → π + π − J/ψ, the different line shape e + e − → π + π − h c makes the understanding of Y states more complicate.

Combining the Born cross sections of e + e − → π 0 π 0 h c with that of charged mode, the ratios of cross section between charged and neutral mode (R ππhc ) at each energy points are calculated, as listed in Table I.
In the calculation, the common systematic uncertainties in the two measurements have been canceled.

The combined ratio for the 3 energy points R ππhc , obtained with a weighted least squares method [27], is determined to be 0.63 ± 0.09, which agrees with the expectation based on isospin symmetry within a systematic uncertainty of 0.5.

IV.
SUMMARY AND OUTLOOK
In summary, the charmoniumlike structure, Z c (4020), has been observed in πh c system for both charged and neutral modes.
It is not only a multi-quark state, but also a isospin triplet.
Table III shows the measured resonance parameters of the charged and neutral Z c (4020) state.
The mass difference between neutral and charged Z c (4020) is 1.0 ± 2.2 (stat.) MeV/c 2 , which in good agreement with zero within uncertainty.

Furthermore, the measured Born cross sections for σ(e + e − → π 0 π 0 h c ) are about half of those for σ(e + e − → π + π − h c ) within errors, while the measured Born cross sections σ(e + e − → π 0 π 0 h c ) for charged and neutral modes.

Furthermore, the measured Born cross sections for σ(e + e − → π 0 π 0 h c ) are about half of those for σ(e + e − → π + π C h c ) within errors, while the measured Born cross sections σ(e + e − → πZ c (4020)) for charged and neutral modes are generally consistent.
It indicates that there is no obvious isospin violations in ππh c and πZ c (4020) systems.
The observation of charged Z c (4020) confirms that there is an extra multi-quark state except the observed Z c (3900).
In particular, c is the first observed neutral charmoniumlike Z state, and it is helpful to understanding the nature of Z c and even other XYZ particles.

For instance, the observation of theoretical expectations of Z c (4020) and X(3872) combined with Y (4260) transition to X(3872), which establish contact with XYZ particles, issue the challenge to interpret these particles theoretically.
Compared to the Z c (4025) observed in the process e + e − → (D * D * ) ± π ∓ [23], the resonance parameters of Z c (4020) [21,22] agree with Z c (4025) [23] with 1.5σ.
If they are the same state, the coupling of Z c (4020) to D * D * final state is about 12 times larger than to πh c final state.
To clarify whether they are the same particle, one needs a further sophisticated analysis with a coupled channel technique.

The observation of charged charmonium-like family members together with the similar observation in bottomonium family provides important evidence for the existence of hadrons beyond the conventional quark model and QCD theory, and helps in the improvement of our understanding about the fundamental structure of the matter.
In the near future, more data between 4.0 and 4.6 GeV at BESIII experiment [24] will be accumulated for further study of XYZ states.
The property of Z c (4020) will be studied more carefully.
Meantime, the line-shape of cross section of e + e − → ππh c and e + e − → πZ c (4020) will be investigated, which can shed light on the understanding of this state and even other XYZ particles,
